qas.question: Northern Germany, Netherlands, northern Poland, Denmark, and the Baltic countries used what building material in place of local stone?
What was the name of the building style that resulted from the use of brick?
What building style was the Hanseatic League connected with in Germany and Scandinavia?
Why were many buildings covered with marble?

answers.text: Because of the extensive and varied deposits of marble

qas.question: With what type of facade were buildings left with if they were to completed at a later time?
What was the name of the building style that resulted from the use of one brick?
What building style was the Hanseatic League disconnected with in Germany and Scandinavia?

plausible_answers.text: Because of the extensive and varied deposits of marble

qas.question: Why were many buildings covered with marbles?
With what type of facade were buildings left with if they were to never be completed at a later time?

context: In Northern Germany, Netherlands, northern Poland, Denmark, and the Baltic countries local building stone was unavailable but there was a strong tradition of building in <a0_0>brick<a0_0/>. The resultant style, <a1_0><b5_0>Brick Gothic<b5_0/>, is called <a2_0><b6_0>"Backsteingotik"<b6_0/><a2_0/><a1_0/> in Germany and Scandinavia and is associated with the Hanseatic League. In Italy, stone was used for fortifications, but brick was preferred for other buildings. <a3_0><b7_0>Because of the extensive and varied deposits of marble<b7_0/><a3_0/>, many buildings were faced in marble, or were left with <a4_0><b8_0>undecorated façade<b8_0/><a4_0/> so that this might be achieved at a later date.
